awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Combining Research and Education via the Exploration of Peptide-Lipid Binding and Aggregation
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Silvina Matysiak from The University of Maryland, College Park to investigate how lipid composition affects peptide self-assembly pathways on a lipid membrane. The project involves the use of computational methods to establish how the chemistry of a lipid headgroup promotes peptide recruitment, misfolding and aggregation in the cases of several amyloidogenic peptides. These studies will provide fundamental information on vital conditions that promote or impede peptide self-assembly and that are responsible for the morphology of the resulting aggregates. The results of this project may be used to understand how protein misfolding in neurons may lead to neuronal dysfunction.   As part of the project, several toolboxes will be created to teach parents and students at the high school and undergraduate levels, the importance of molecular interactions in the everyday world. In order to achieve this goal, real-time videos of living cells or animations will be combined with interactive hands-on modeling of proteins.

There is a fundamental gap in understanding how proteins misfold and aggregate on cellular membranes. This project involves a computational investigation that aims at elucidating how membrane composition modulates amyloid peptide aggregation. A deeper understanding of the driving forces behind peptide aggregation on membranous surfaces would have impact on a number of disciplines ranging from biomaterials to biotechnology. The approaches involve an expansion of a previously developed coarse-grained model in the context of this project.  The project aims to 1) study the role of peptide-lipid hydrogen bonds in peptide aggregation, 2) quantify the impact of electrostatic interactions in shaping aggregation pathways, 3) dissect the influence of multivalent ions in lipid domain formations and how this affects peptide energy landscapes and 4) characterize how changes in a membrane's physical properties can modify peptide aggregation behavior. The computational models developed in this award will be made freely available to the public.

por.por_cntn:
With this award the research group of Dr. Silvina Matysiak investigated how environmental factors present in cellular environments affects peptide self assembly. Peptides are molecules composed of amino acids and they can achieve unique shapes by a process called peptide folding.  In cellular environments peptides can also aggregate.  Peptide folding and/or aggregation can be promoted, disturbed or inhibited by the presence of other molecules.  We utilize computational methods to establish how the chemistry of a lipid (a component of a cellular membrane) and other molecules can tune peptide recruitment, misfolding and aggregation in cellular membranes. Cellular membranes are multicomponent double layers of lipid molecules (lipid bilayer) that create a surface envelope.

New computational models of peptides and lipids (a component of cellular membranes) were developed under this award. These models allow us to computationally study peptide aggregation on membranes, which was challenging previously. From our computer simulations, we discovered that for peptide folding to occur on a lipid bilayer a unique balance of interactions between peptide-peptide and peptide-lipids is needed. If peptides interacts too strongly with lipids then folding do not occur. Also, we observed that certain type of peptide-peptide interactions is what drives peptide aggregation on lipid surfaces (peptide backbone interactions and not hydrophobicity).  In addition, we characterized the mechanism by which certain lipids can promote peptide misfolding and aggregation on lipid surfaces using peptides that can cause toxic aggregation, which can lead to neuronal dysfunction. We have also discovered the reason of why the curvature of a membrane can modulate peptide aggregation.

Many peptides that can aggregate on cellular membranes have a lipid-binding domain (a part of the peptide that more favorably interacts with lipids) that can sense membrane curvature. In this award, we have also focused on how these lipid-binding domains can detect different membrane curvatures affecting peptide aggregation.

Celullar membranes can respond to interactions with neighboring molecules such as peptides, ions and polyssacharides. Some lipid species can interact more favorably with absorbing molecules leading to lipids migrating towards the interacting molecules, exchanging with less favorably interacting lipids, which migrates away from this zone causing lipid demixing. This demixing process is involved in many key regulatory mechanisms in cellular signal processing. Lipid demixing can also influence peptide misfolding and aggregation and peptide aggregation on lipid surfaces can also cause lipid demixing. To study such a phenomenon, we focused on what are the driving forces behind calcium effects on membrane remodeling using model membranes composed of neutral and negatively charged lipids. Because lipid membranes are elastic, the absorption of calcium ions led to local changes in membrane curvature in negatively charged lipid domains. Calcium acts as a glue of negatively charged lipid molecules leading to their aggregation.

To summarize, our studies have provided fundamental information on vital conditions that promote or impede peptide aggregation and that are responsible for the shape of the resulting aggregates. The results of this project can be used to understand how peptide misfolding/aggregation in neurons may lead to neuronal dysfunction. In addition, we developed a new set of computational models that can be used by other researchers to characterize other biological processes.

 As part of the project, several toolboxes were created to teach parents and students at the high school and undergraduate levels, the importance of molecular interactions in the everyday world. In order to achieve this goal, we combined real-time videos of living cells and animations with interactive hands-on modeling of proteins. These toolboxes were used in several outreach activities at the University of Maryland as well as in computational courses taught by the principal investigator.
